title: Stour and Orwell Walk Route

images.title: Bob Jones / River Stour from the clifftop
images.caption: River Stour from the clifftop, east of Cattawade. The waymarked Stour and Orwell Walk is sited on the low wooded cliff, from where there is an excellent view upstream of the River Stour, together with the remains of a former jetty.

images.title: Bob Jones / Footpath along Levington Creek
images.caption: Footpath along Levington Creek. This path follows the west bank of Levington Creek, an arm of the River Orwell.

images.title: Bob Jones / Two country seats
images.caption: Two country seats. The more imposing 'seat' is Broke Hall, the former home of naval hero Captain Philip Broke.  The wooden seat is one of a pair, close to the trail. It overlooks the River Orwell and the village of Pin Mill on the opposite bank.

images.title: Bob Jones / Footpath to Stutton Ness
images.caption: Footpath to Stutton Ness

images.title: Stour and Orwell Walk - Warren Bottom by Robin Lucas, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Warren Bottom

images.title: Stour and Orwell Walk, looking towards the Port of Felixstowe by Hamish Griffin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking towards the Port of Felixstowe

description: Follow the Rivers Orwell and the Stour on this walk through the Suffolk Coast and Heaths Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The walk begins on the Suffolk Coast at Felixstowe and soon turns north along the River Orwell for a waterside stretch towards Ipswich, passing the riverside Orwell Country Park, the lovely beach at Nacton Shores and Trimley Marshes Nature Reserve on the way. You then turn south along the western side of the Orwell towards Shotley Gate where you join the River Stour for the final stretch to Cattawade. This section passes the delightful Pin Mill where you can see lots of little boats in the river and enjoy refreshments at the 17th century Butt and Oyster pub. The trail is fairly flat for most of the way and runs for just over 40 miles.
